doc.field: Schroeder: No comment on Lafontaine book

Chancellor Schroeder refused official comment towards criticism from former SPD leader Oskar Lafontaine. It would have been better if Lafontaine had spoken with him, as well as other SPD and Green politicians, personally, said Schroeder last night on ARD. Lafontaine sharply attacked the head of the red-green coalition in his book, "The Heart Beats Left," and suggests Schroeder deceived voters. The book will be published in excerpts by the "World on Sunday" paper.
Union wants to stop Bundesrat's reform plans

The CDU will block reform plans of the federal government in the Bundesrat. According to CDU Chairman Schaeuble, the party leadership is in agreement that the union-led states will refuse the health reform and savings plans for economic rehabilitation in its present form. The CDU leadership agreed with the CSU leader last night.
Union parties work out savings program

The CDU and CSU want to reduce their somewhat different approaches to tax policy by finding a common denominator. The goal of the meeting is an alternative program to the Federal government's savings package. The CSU jumped the start with a proposal to reduce the top tax bracket in two steps through to the year 2003 from 52% to 35%.
Greens want separation of mandate and party office

The Greens want to abolish the strict separaton of mandate and party office, but keep the double leadership. The federal representative of the Greens supports this reform proposal of the internal party structure commision. Council spokesperson Radcke said after the meeting in Berlin that the federal council doesn't think creating the post of General Secretary makes sense, as suggested by Foreign Minister Fischer. Constitutional changes for the Greens have to be approved by two-thirds of a federal party convention. The reform proposals will be discussed in state councils for the Greens. This convention will meet mid-October in Magdeburg.
Still 30,000 without apprenticeship position

About 30,000 young adults in Germany are still looking for apprenticeship positions, according to the Frankfurter Rundschau at the beginning of the education year. According to the paper's figures, trade offered 184,000 training positions, and it looks better in industry and business. In those areas, 300,000 training contracts were signed, up by more than 10% from last year. The increase is possible due to the government's immediate program.
Zwickel criticizes government's savings plans

IG-metall Chairman Zwickel has once again criticized the savings plans of the federal goverment as unfair towords retirees, the unemployed, and social aid recipients. An especially high amount is demanded from these groups, while the wealthy aren't required to pay more, said Zwickel to BILD. The unionist promoted a property levy that should flow into innovation funds for research and development and ecological projects.
Compromise in fight on retirement age

Both sides in the fight about retiremtn at age 60, the Federal Government and IG-Metall, have indicatied readiness to compromise. At the IG-Metall congress in Hamburg, Employment Minister Riester said today he wants to seek talks with IG Metall and retiree insurance carriers. IG-Metall Chairman Zwickel spoke of a favorable fundamental basis for a solution in this conflict.
Bank merger falls through

A large merger of the Deutsche and Dresdner Banks in personal banking has fallen through. Both institutions made known last night that the proceedings ended without a solid result. Accrding to the Dresdner Bank, cooperation for customers, and thus the whole bank, would have been bound to too many restrictions.
France Telecom buys into E-Plus

France Telecom has entered into the German market. The corporation bought 3.4 billion Marks worth of shares from the Essen-based mobile communicaions provider E-Plus. The British mobile communication company Woderforn Airtouch (sp?) was also in on the deal. After the failure of merger plans, the French are going their own way into the German telephone market.
Gas explosion kills 2

A gas explosion killed two girls, age 9 and 11, in Monheim, near Leverkusen, North Rhine-Westphalia. The girls were taking a bath while visiting their grandparents when a gas bottle allegedly exploded. The grandparents and the girls' father were critically injured, the grandfather teetering on the brink of life and death. The house was mostly destroyed; surrounding buildings also sustained damage.
